end.creator_credit: Charles Roven
end.brief_description: In the year 2035, convict James Cole reluctantly volunteers to be sent back in time to discover the origin of a deadly virus that wiped out nearly all of the earth’s population and forced the survivors into underground communities.

constellations_other.name: There's always a lighthouse

links.description: Bioshock Infinite explores themes of choice, fatalism, predeterminism and the multiple worlds theory. Twelve Monkeys explores similar themes, arguing particularly for hard determinism, the belief that our lives are prewritten and inescapable. Both works feature time traveling to avoid fate.

links.description: Twelve Monkeys was heavily inspired by French science-fiction featurette La Jetée by Chris Marker. Both films explore the nature of time travel and its consequences on free will and fate.

constellations_other.name: Obviously the time continuum has been disrupted...again and again and again!
constellations_other.description: Eadweard Muybridge was able to capture time and play it back again creating endless time paradoxes where subjects are destined to repeat their previous actions. Filmmakers have since explored such notions via time travel narratives questioning destiny, fate and choice.

links.description: Dark delves into the problems and intricacies of time travel, and how it negates ideas of free will. Many characters are trapped in predetermined loops that they participate in either actively or inadvertently through what they perceive as free will.

links.description: Rithy Panh’s The Missing Picture tries to create context and history – the missing visual evidence – of both Cambodia’s culturally rich past and the Khmer Rouge’s violence. He uses a range of techniques to render what was lost including clay figures and dioramas.

end.title: Coat hangers
end.brief_description: “No! Wire! Hangers … ever!” The now famous line from 1981 kitsch classic Mommie Dearest depicted coat hangers as the bane of Joan Crawford’s existence (among other things). And while that might be true in the context of this docudrama, they’ve also been a consistent presence on film sets since the dawn of the moving image. Practical and ingenious, coat hangers come in all shapes and sizes. This simple domestic object has been handmade or manufactured in wood, metal, plastic or wire. (The wire ones could also be bent into a map-of-Australia car aerial!) Coat hangers are an essential tool in the costume department.

links.description: Feud details the rivalry between Joan Crawford and Bette Davis. In Mommie Dearest, Crawford is played by Faye Dunaway, and in the film’s most memorable scene, furiously declares “No! Wire! Hangers!… ever!”

end.title: Stand Inside Your Love
end.brief_description: “Stand Inside Your Love” is a song by American alternative rock band the Smashing Pumpkins. The music video of “Stand Inside Your Love” is a tribute to the play Salomé by Oscar Wilde.

constellations_other.name: Using the silent film aesthetic
constellations_other.description: Explore how contemporary filmmakers use visual references to the silent era to convey information to a film literate audience.

links.description: Visionary director W.I.Z. (Andrew Whiston) payed homage to Salomé in the music video for ‘Stand Inside Your Love’ by The Smashing Pumpkins. Stark black and white photography is used to reference Aubrey Beardsley who illustrated Oscar Wilde’s Salomé.

start.title: Dracula: Pages from a Virgin's Diary
start.creator_credit: Paul Daigle, Vonnie Von Helmolt, CBC and Deanne Rohde
start.brief_description: A cinematic version of the Royal Winnipeg Ballet’s adaptation of Bram Stoker’s Gothic novel Dracula, filmed in a style reminiscent of silent Expressionist cinema of the early 20th century, complete with inter-titles and monochrome photography.

constellations_other.name: Using the silent film aesthetic
constellations_other.description: Explore how contemporary filmmakers use visual references to the silent era to convey information to a film literate audience.

end.title: The Artist
end.creator_credit: Jean Dujardin and Thomas Langmann
end.brief_description: Hollywood, 1927: as silent movie star George Valentin wonders if the arrival of talking pictures will cause him to fade into oblivion, he sparks with Peppy Miller, a young dancer set for a big break.

constellations_other.name: Using the silent film aesthetic
constellations_other.description: Explore how contemporary filmmakers use visual references to the silent era to convey information to a film literate audience.

constellations_other.name: Boom mics, Clara Bow and musicals
constellations_other.description: The microphone was called the "terror of the studios" when sound films were introduced in the late 1920s, but after initial resistance Hollywood fully embraced the new technology.

links.description: Michel Hazanavicius’ mostly-silent film The Artist marked a significant shift from this aesthetic being used as a referential touching point or avant-garde experiment to a work with more of a mainstream appeal. Stylistic nods to the era are more polished.

start.title: Magnolia
start.creator_credit: Daniel Lupi, Dylan Tichenor, JoAnne Sellar, Paul Thomas Anderson and William Arnold
start.brief_description: Paul Thomas Anderson’s epic mosaic of interrelated characters search for happiness, forgiveness and meaning in the San Fernando Valley. Featuring a star-studded cast including Tom Cruise, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Julianne Moore and William H Macy.

constellations_other.name: Using the silent film aesthetic
constellations_other.description: Explore how contemporary filmmakers use visual references to the silent era to convey information to a film literate audience.

end.title: Sissy-Boy Slap-Party
end.creator_credit: Meg McMillan, Jody Shapiro, Phyllis Lang, Réjean Labrie and Guy Maddin
end.brief_description: Sailors on an island paradise don’t have a worry in the world — until a playful gesture is interpreted as an act of wilful aggression in Guy Maddin’s experimental short. Soon, the innocent act of slight slapping becomes a relentless orgy of face-smacking.

constellations_other.name: Using the silent film aesthetic
constellations_other.description: Explore how contemporary filmmakers use visual references to the silent era to convey information to a film literate audience.

links.description: Many silent films were shot on hand-cranked cameras causing variable speeds. In the opening sequence of Magnolia, the film is sped up to signify the silent era, however in Sissy-Boy Slap-Party this is further exaggerated to reference slapstick.

constellations_other.name: Boom mics, Clara Bow and musicals
constellations_other.description: The microphone was called the "terror of the studios" when sound films were introduced in the late 1920s, but after initial resistance Hollywood fully embraced the new technology.

links.description: The Artist relies on similar silent era visual cues as Sissy-Boy Slap Party – similar lighting, and variable speeds - however they are less exaggerated and create a very different mood throughout the film.

end.creator_credit: Daniel Lupi, Dylan Tichenor, JoAnne Sellar, Paul Thomas Anderson and William Arnold
end.brief_description: Paul Thomas Anderson’s epic mosaic of interrelated characters search for happiness, forgiveness and meaning in the San Fernando Valley. Featuring a star-studded cast including Tom Cruise, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Julianne Moore and William H Macy.

constellations_other.name: Using the silent film aesthetic
constellations_other.description: Explore how contemporary filmmakers use visual references to the silent era to convey information to a film literate audience.

links.description: Magnolia’s memorable opening vignette is shot in black and white, within a 4:3 frame and with visual effects implying film degradation and a significant flicker. This aesthetic is used to articulate a temporal shift to the audience.

results.name: Capturing first-person POV
results.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

key_work.title: GoPro Hero 3
key_work.brief_description: The GoPro was designed as an action camera, making it as tough and durable as whatever adventure the shooter was partaking in. Originally invented for surf photography, they’re made to be attached to a body or moving object.

constellations_primary.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_primary.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

start.title: GoldenEye 007
start.brief_description: GoldenEye 007 inspired endless fun when it was released on the Nintendo 64 – just as long as you didn’t look at anyone’s screen or play as Odd Job. One of the first multi-player first-person-shooters for console, GoldenEye made everyone 007.

constellations_other.name: Gunslingers, good fellas and flea bags
constellations_other.description: Explore how a 1903 western changed the course of filmmaking and videogames by breaking the fourth wall.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_other.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

recommendations.quote: There's never been a better adaptation of film into a videogame than Golden Eye. For the first time, up to four players could shoot it out on one TV screen and take control of one of some of cinema's best heroes and villains. And yes, Odd Job is cheating.

end.title: Maze War
end.creator_credit: Steve Colley, Greg Thompson and Howard Palmer
end.brief_description: Without Maze War, there wouldn’t be any first-person shooter videogames like Quake or Doom. Developed by Steve Cooley for NASA, Maze War featured forward, backwards, left and right movements, as well as first-person perspective.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_other.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

links.description: GoldenEye 007 is a descendent of Maze War (1973), a computer game developed by Steve Cooley for NASA which is considered one of the original first-person shooters.

end.brief_description: A withdrawn psychopath films young women as he impales them with the camera’s tripod, forcing them to watch their own death throes in a mirror mounted on the camera. Now considered a masterpiece, Michael Powell’s film foreshadowed the slasher genre.

links.description: Before Strange Days, POV shots were slower and less dynamic because of the size and weight of 35mm cameras. But they were still effective and terrified audiences in Peeping Tom, one of the first films to show a killer’s POV.

links.description: By the time Banksy’s documentary Exit Through the Gift Shop was released in 2010, artists like Banksy and Invader had achieved cult-like status and exploring streets for their works had become a very common activity.

start.title: Wayfinder Live (2016)
start.brief_description: In 2016 Swinburne University developed a location-based game designed for councils to increase social connection. Users were rewarded with unlockable augmented/mixed reality artworks throughout Melbourne.

results.name: Evolution of colour
results.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

key_work.title: Stencil colouring
key_work.brief_description: When Alexandre Volkoff brought the story of history’s greatest lover to the screen in Casanova (1927), he definitely needed colour. Pathé Frères developed a stencil technqiue for colouring films that brought Casanova’s costumes alive and colour to his lovers’ cheeks.

start.title: A Visit to the Seaside
start.creator_credit: George Albert Smith
start.brief_description: The first successful motion picture in the Kinemacolor system, this eight minute short from George Albert Smith showed people in Brighton, England doing everyday activities. Kinemacolor later influenced and was then replaced by Technicolor.

end.brief_description: The Gulf Between is a 1917 American comedy drama film that was the first motion picture made in Technicolor, the fourth feature-length color movie, and the first feature-length color movie produced in the United States.

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: Kinemacolor was an important influence on the popular Technicolor system, which went through several developments. The first, Process 1, used red and green filters like Kinemacolor. The only filmed produced in Process 1 Technicolor is The Gulf Between.

start.title: Loves of Casanova
start.creator_credit: Ciné-Alliance, Deulig Film, Société des Cinéromans, Noë Bloch, Alexandre Volkoff, Ivan Mosjoukine and Norbert Falk
start.brief_description: Republic of Venice, 1760. Pursued by a vengeful husband, the intrepid womanizer Casanova, who symbolizes the decline of the city and its fall into debauchery, manages to escape and, by a circuitous route, arrives in Saint Petersburg, where he will be involved in the many plots that threaten the throne of Czar Peter III…

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour

constellations_other.name: Evolution of colour
constellations_other.description: From stenciling film frames through to the survival of Technicolor after Hollywood stopped using it, this Constellation links early cinema to some of the world's greatest films.

links.description: Casanova was coloured by Pathé Frères’ stencil process, which used a template for each colour and applied it frame-by-frame. Almost 20 years earlier, the British Kinemacolour system used red and green filters to colour A Visit to the Seaside.

end.title: Kinemacolor

results.name: Good vibrations
results.description: Since its invention, the humble theremin has been used in a number of different ways to evoke all sorts of strange sounds and moods.

key_work.title: Percy Grainger's MOOG Theremin
key_work.brief_description: Cinema audiences were first introduced to the eerie vibrations of a theremin in the Soviet film Odna (Alone) (1931). During a snowstorm, composer Dimitri Shostakovish amps up the dread with the theremin’s high-pitched wail. Invented in 1920 by Russian physicist Léon Theremin, the instrument works by harnessing electricity and has been used in movies ever since, from The Day the Earth Stood Still (1951) to First Man (2018). In 1932, Australian composer Percy Grainger discovered the instrument (this one is signed by him) and used it to develop compositions that weren’t dictated by scales, rhythms or harmonies.

links.description: When most people think about Technicolor, they think about The Wizard of Oz. As Dorothy steps out of her dreary sepia life and into Munchkinland, she’s enveloped in glorious Technicolor.

start.title: The Wizard of Oz
start.creator_credit: Adrian, Arthur Freed, Mervyn LeRoy, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer and Malcolm Brown
start.brief_description: When a tornado rips through Kansas, Dorothy (Judy Garland) and her dog, Toto, are whisked away in their house to the magical land of Oz. They follow the Yellow Brick Road toward the Emerald City to meet the Wizard, and encounter a Scarecrow, a Tin Man and a Cowardly Lion.

end.title: Flowers and Trees
end.creator_credit: Walt Disney
end.brief_description: Flowers and Trees is a 1932 Silly Symphonies cartoon produced by Walt Disney, directed by Burt Gillett, and released on July 30, 1932. It was the first commercially released film to be produced in the full-color three-strip Technicolor process.

links.description: One of the first and most iconic films released in Technicolor was The Wizard of Oz, though the three-strip Technicolor process was first used by Disney for their animated short film Flowers and Trees.

end.title: Suspiria
end.creator_credit: Dario Argento and Claudio Argento
end.brief_description: From the moment she arrives in Germany to attend the prestigious Tanz Academy, American ballet-dancer Suzy Bannion (Jessica Harper) senses that something horribly evil lurks within the walls of the age-old institution.

constellations_other.name: The Suspense Constellation
constellations_other.description: An exploration of music in suspense works.

constellations_other.name: Breaking the binary
constellations_other.description: Tilda Swinton name has become synonymous with androgyny since she first appeared on our screens in the mid-1980s, leading a cultural shift towards today’s understanding of gender as fluid and ever-changing. Orlando was key to establishing her influence and allure.

links.description: The Wizard of Oz embraced the effect of Technicolor to portray a dream-like fantasy world. Suspiria went a different way, using Technicolor to create a heavily saturated, nightmarish atmosphere.

end.creator_credit: Charles Evans Jr., Graham King, Matthias Deyle, Michael Mann and Sandy Climan
end.headline_credit: Germany and United States of America, 2004

video_links.name: The Aviator | Official Trailer (HD) - Leonardo DiCaprio, Kate Beckinsale, Cate Blanchett | MIRAMAX

end.brief_description: A biopic charting the life of filmmaker and aviation magnate Howard Hughes between 1927 and 47, when his meteoric rise was impacted by his severe obsessive-compulsive disorder. Directed by Scorsese, digitally emulated the look of Technicolor to reflect the film’s era.

constellations_other.name: Some like it hot
constellations_other.description: Australian costume designer Orry-Kelly had an eye for designing exceptional garments that worked for non-traditional Hollywood figures. His talent was highlighted when creating the gender non-conforming costumes for characters Joe / Josephine (Tony Curtis) and Jerry / Daphne (Jack Lemmon).

constellations_other.name: Movies in movies in a movie museum
constellations_other.description: The 400 Porto-Arc 16mm projector used the first electric light ever invented, which was perfectly suited for movie projectors. This Constellation explores the movies where characters go to the movies, by two movie-obsessed directors.

links.description: While Suspiria was one of the last films to be made before the Technicolor process was phased out, The Aviator digitally emulated the look of Technicolor films between 1927 and 1947, which is the period the film is set.

end.title: Cuphead
end.brief_description: Cuphead is a classic run and gun action game inspired by cartoons of the 1930s, with the visuals and audio painstakingly created with the same techniques of the era like traditional cel animation, watercolor backgrounds, and original jazz recordings.

constellations_other.description: Though VFX continues to push boundaries and brings fantastical worlds and creatures to life, there's still a place for classic animation techniques.

constellations_other.name: Timeless early animation
constellations_other.description: This Constellation traces the inspirations and evolution of the Cuphead animation technique and franchise back to the early 20th century and beyond.

links.description: Flowers and Trees helped define the visual style of early animation. Videogame Cuphead uses an animation style that pays homage to this Technicolor era, even using many of the animation techniques that appeared in Flowers and Trees.
